Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Modeling and Estimation of Dynamic High-latitude Ionospheric Loss and Transport Processes
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigator will study the details of ionospheric source dynamics through synergistic use of two- and three- dimensional models and new estimation schemes involving both incoherent scatter radar and optical spectrograph data. High-latitude ionospheric plasma density and structure play a critical role in the coupled terrestrial ionosphere-thermosphere-magnetosphere (ITM) system. Experimental and modeling studies have convincingly demonstrated the presence of heavy ions of ionospheric origin in various magnetospheric regions, and that these heavy ions appreciably affect response of the ITM system to solar wind forcing. The ionospheric source and its dynamics play a substantial role in modulating this ion outflow process. This research will directly address several gaps in the current ability to observe the composition of the high-latitude ionospheric plasma and our understanding of the temporally dynamic nature of heating events and associated transients governing composition, ionospheric upflows, and the generation of mesoscale and small-scale ionospheric plasma density structures. Specific science objectives will be to provide detailed data-model analyses to determine the: (1) Location and intensity of storm-time ionospheric sources for molecular ion outflow (2) Contributions of molecular ion recombination, current closure depletion, and ion upflows to plasma loss in realistic auroral current systems (3) Time scales on which major ionospheric loss and transport processes operate, including the effects of electromagnetic induction in highly dynamic situations (4) Effects of three-dimensional current system geometries on ionospheric transport and loss, and the role of these processes in the development of smaller-scale irregularities (5) Temporal dependence of low altitude upflow, including transients in upflow initiation and finite propagation times to higher altitudes, and possible influence of some types of wave-particle interactions on upflow. The early career scientist leading this project will focus on supporting a new PhD program in Engineering Physics at ERAU, including funding of students completing MS and PhD theses, and refinement of the PI's MS and PhD courses to include contemporary space physics research topics where appropriate, and student research projects. Efforts to support undergraduate research will continue through funded summer projects, independent studies, and development of a new, year-long senior thesis option for highly qualified students. This project will support and further develop new and existing academic programs, is heavily pitched toward both undergraduate and graduate student involvement, and is specifically intended to work in concert with the university-wide student research initiative IGNITE. Research results will be made available through prompt publication, and it is anticipated that many of the contributions will yield student-authored papers. The research undertaken will represent an international collaboration with both European and South American institutions supporting some aspects of the work. Methods developed for addressing the science goals above (i.e. models and estimation schemes), will likely serve as useful tools for the community to use in other related studies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ionized portion of the Earth?s atmosphere, the ionosphere, forms several layers extending from 80-1000 kilometers in altitude.  The ionospheric plasma is subjected to a wide range of energy inputs:  energetic particle and electromagnetic energy inputs from the overlying magnetosphere (itself receiving energy from the solar wind), solar radiation, and upward propagating atmospheric disturbances.  One general manifestation of these inputs is the production of density structures in the ionosphere - these can be used to monitor atmospheric and ground-level activity and evaluate effects of ionospheric escape, or they can cascade into turbulence capable of disrupting radio signal propagation through the near-earth space environment.  

 

Specific examples of density structuring mechanisms include dissipation of electromagnetic energy near auroras which can result in alterations ionospheric chemistry resulting in density depletions.  Additionally, auroral energetic electrons flowing in to the atmosphere can also heat the plasma resulting in expansion and ionospheric outflow (an escape process).  Meanwhile, atmospheric waves sourced from lower altitudes (via weather or seismic sources) imprint themselves into the ionospheric plasma, making them detectable via radio probing techniques.  Effects of all of these processes are routinely visible in ionospheric data, yet the chain of causative physical processes leading to observed characteristics in the data are poorly understood.  This prevents accurate prediction, data inversion, or a detailed assessment of the impact of these processes beyond the fact that they are generally known to have important effects.  The purpose of this project was to study fundamental physical processes related to ionospheric density structuring due to atmospheric wave and magnetospheric energy inputs and to assess cascade of density structures through plasma instability and turbulence.  

 

Intellectual Merit:  This project involved creation of a new software, GEMINI, for purposes of studying the Earth?s ionosphere at a wide range of locations (i.e. both high latitudes and low latitudes) for a flexible range of energy inputs.  GEMINI has the unique ability to capture physical details of the ionospheric plasma at small scales relevant to studying auroras, ionospheric escape, the production of plasma turbulence, and effects of atmospheric waves.  This model has been used to address aspects of ionospheric behavior related to density structuring, instability, and outflow as briefly outlined here.  GEMINI has been used to simulate ionospheric density cavity formation due to combined effects of chemical alterations and electrical current closure through the E-region ionosphere, demonstrating the likely dominance of chemical processes for larger cavities often visible in ionospheric radar data.  The ionospheric response to atmospheric waves generated by weather-related and seismic events has been substantially clarified using the GEMINI models validated against available GPS data.  This work has shown that, given proper source specification for convective thunderstorms or earthquakes, our model can accurate capture many, if not most, of the features evident in GPS-TEC data.  This provides a promising future avenue to predicting effects of large events and interpreting TEC data qualitatively to infer information about lower atmospheric or ground-level disturbances.  Simulation work from this project has, further, shown the degree to which atmospheric winds and wave-like disturbances can contribute to ionospheric escape and has also illustrated how non-steady energy inputs impact escape.  Finally, we have contributed to development of a new modeling approach which can simulate ionospheric turbulence at high latitudes and the propagation/scattering of radio through this turbulence using a pure physics-based approach.  This technique has been applied to several studies of radio signal disruption and seems a promising and useful tool for developing a better understanding of these events through ongoing and future work.  

 

Broader Impacts:  The project has supported a number of graduate students in the completion of their degrees including 2 PhD students and 3 Master?s students.  The GEMINI software and related simulation tools used in this project have been open sourced and released to the public for general and scientific use (https://github.com/gemini3d) under a permissive license.  Supported efforts also included development contributing to two courses at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University:  EP 410 (Space Physics) and EP 509 (Advanced Space Physics).  Work has focused on conversion of these course over to a project-based format where students were guided toward completion of development-based projects (EP 410), or encouraged to engage in a substantial research projects of their own choosing, related to space physics (EP 509).
